               <section display-inline="no-display-inline"
                         id="HB9A472180AC74808B48DA5EDD67B81F0"
                         qb-display-quote="yes"
                         section-type="subsequent-section">
                  206.
                  ADDRESSING OPERATIONAL BARRIERS TO PROMOTE CONTINUITY OF CARE FOR MEDICAID AND CHIP
       BENEFICIARIES FOLLOWING INCARCERATION
                  
                     42 USC 1396a note.
                  
                  <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                               id="H3D7A5EF9F36F4F018267D566854E3854"
                               qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (a)
                     State planning grants
                     <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                 id="H1AE0628C11A844CAA204464A35D71BAF"
                                 qb-display-quote="yes">
                        (1)
                        In general
                        
                           Deadline.
                        
                        Not later than 12 months after the date of enactment of this Act, the Secretary shall
         award grants to States for the purpose of developing operational capabilities to promote
         continuity of care for individuals who are inmates of a public institution and are eligible
         for medical assistance under the State Medicaid program or are eligible for child
           
                              138 STAT. 407
                           
         health assistance or pregnancy-related assistance under the State CHIP.
                     
                     <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                 id="H345C6AA77E804F0A81F20624250D5198"
                                 qb-display-quote="yes">
                        (2)
                        Use of funds
                        
                           Compliance.
                        
                        A State may use funds awarded under a grant under this subsection for activities and
         expenses related to complying with the requirement described in section 1902(a)(84)(A) of
         the Social Security Act (42 U.S.C.
          1396a(a)(84)(A)) that a State shall not terminate eligibility for medical
         assistance, complying with the requirements of sections 1902(a)(84)(D) and 2102(d) of the
         Social Security Act (42 U.S.C.
          1396a(a)(84)(D), 1397bb(d)), or adopting the State plan options described in the
         subdivision (A) following the last numbered paragraph of section 1905(a) and 2110(b)(7) of
         the Social Security Act (42 U.S.C.
          1396d(a), 1397jj(b)(7)), or other activities and expenses to promote continuity
         of care for individuals described in paragraph (1). Such activities and expenses may
         include— 
                        <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                       id="HBA6B0025D66C4AA2B57EF70137D1AF96"
                                       qb-display-quote="yes">
                           (A)
                           identifying and addressing operational gaps with respect to complying with such
          requirements or adopting such options, in collaboration with public institutions, State
          human services agencies, Medicaid managed care plans, providers, community-based
          organizations, and other stakeholders;
                        
                        <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                       id="HD5CAAF40B6AB49B58FD1D72B5AD03D81"
                                       qb-display-quote="yes">
                           (B)
                           establishing standardized processes and automated systems for activities that may
          include, but are not limited to— 
                           <clause display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                    id="HD1907BE8D3AA4AA78621B570F8F196B0"
                                    qb-display-quote="yes">
                              (i)
                              determining whether an individual is enrolled in a State Medicaid program or State
           CHIP at the time such individual becomes an inmate of a public institution;
                              
                                 Determinations.
                              
                           
                           <clause display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                    id="H160D339A83154CD2AB153A8962A53535"
                                    qb-display-quote="yes">
                              (ii)
                              allowing an individual who is an inmate of a public institution to submit an
           application to enroll or renew coverage in a State Medicaid program or State CHIP prior
           to the individual's release from such public institution; 
                           
                           <clause display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                    id="HA5D08FE03EED4F87B148C4EC29F4F577"
                                    qb-display-quote="yes">
                              (iii)
                              facilitating the delivery of medical assistance under the State Medicaid program or
           child health assistance or pregnancy-related assistance under the State CHIP to an
           individual who is eligible for such assistance while the individual is an inmate of a
           public institution, such as by establishing claims processing and prior authorization
           request protocols; and 
                           
                           <clause display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                    id="H6D1CE64805CC48CA9DBB4058CECC3D05"
                                    qb-display-quote="yes">
                              (iv)
                              in the case of an eligible individual whose coverage under a State Medicaid program
           or State CHIP was suspended while the individual was an inmate of a public institution,
           restoring such coverage upon such individual's release from the public
           institution;
                           
                        
                        <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                       id="HBFF2E1056262423EBFD0A10BDB58804A"
                                       qb-display-quote="yes">
                           (C)
                           investing in information technology to—
                           <clause display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                    id="H2C93664230C04FEEA0B2C739C1679841"
                                    qb-display-quote="yes">
                              (i)
                              enable bi-directional information sharing between public institutions, the State
           Medicaid and CHIP agencies, and other entities such as managed care plans and providers
           (in a manner consistent with applicable State and Federal privacy laws), to support care
           transitions and coordination of treatment (including access to care in the community
           after release from a public institution); and 
                                    138 STAT. 408
                                 
                              
                           
                           <clause display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                    id="H847F3E8922F947A1BB30A187ABB4A90A"
                                    qb-display-quote="yes">
                              (ii)
                              develop indicators to ensure Federal financial participation for medical assistance
           furnished under a State Medicaid program or child health assistance or pregnancy-related
           assistance furnished under a State CHIP is available only for medical assistance or child
           health assistance or pregnancy-related assistance for items and services for which such
           participation is permitted while an individual is an inmate of a public institution;
           and
                           
                        
                        <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                       id="H85ECF1A5AE44432DA85D289B003F2D54"
                                       qb-display-quote="yes">
                           (D)
                           establishing oversight and monitoring processes to ensure public institutions and
          entities with which they contract are compliant with any applicable Medicaid and CHIP
          requirements.
                        
                     
                     <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                 id="H39C99CC2FE314125B5D3B7C35F14B054"
                                 qb-display-quote="yes">
                        (3)
                        Limitations on use of funds
                        A State shall not use funds from a grant awarded under this subsection to— 
                        <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                       id="H2D30134BF4184B1EA6F94F2CCAB2D1B0"
                                       qb-display-quote="yes">
                           (A)
                           provide medical assistance under a State Medicaid program or child health assistance
          or pregnancy-related assistance under a State CHIP to an individual, or otherwise directly
          administer health care services for an individual; or
                        
                        <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                       id="H23A915ED70F241C085209E9F8AAFC546"
                                       qb-display-quote="yes">
                           (B)
                           build prisons, jails, or other carceral facilities, or pay for prison, jail, or other
          carceral facility-related improvements other than those improvements that are for the
          direct and primary purpose of meeting the health care needs of individuals who are
          incarcerated and who are eligible for medical assistance under the State Medicaid program
          or child health assistance or pregnancy-related assistance under the State CHIP. 
                        
                     
                     <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                 id="HD873F07BC51E4635A54A1B915E36D843"
                                 qb-display-quote="yes">
                        (4)
                        Allocation of grant funds
                        
                           Determinations.
                        
                        In determining the amount of a grant to award to a State that applies for a grant
         under this subsection, the Secretary shall consider the following factors, relative to
         other States applying for grants under this subsection:
                        <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                       id="HDFBF8836C53B436A891EDD00BCE4BB0E"
                                       qb-display-quote="yes">
                           (A)
                           The number of individuals in the State who were inmates of non-Federal public
          institutions (such as State prisons, local and county jails, tribal jails, and youth
          correctional or detention facilities) and were eligible for medical assistance under a
          State Medicaid program at any time in calendar year 2022.
                        
                        <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                       id="H9F6517EC1A5D4693B0358D5594DAB55E"
                                       qb-display-quote="yes">
                           (B)
                           The number of non-Federal public institutions in the State (such as State prisons,
          local and county jails, tribal jails, and youth correctional or detention
          facilities).
                        
                        <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                       id="H5E208D228F8647E5B66D15B94B2703AB"
                                       qb-display-quote="yes">
                           (C)
                           The State’s progress in developing, implementing, and operating initiatives to
          promote continuity of care for individuals who are inmates of a public institution and are
          eligible for medical assistance under the State Medicaid program or are eligible for child
          health assistance or pregnancy-related assistance under the State CHIP (with favorable
          consideration given to States with less progress in promoting continuity of care for such
          individuals). 
                        
                     
                     <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                 id="H66F7897DE0AE4C84A741D576A11563C6"
                                 qb-display-quote="yes">
                        (5)
                        Appropriation
                        There is appropriated to the Secretary for fiscal year 2024, out of any funds in the
         Treasury not otherwise appropriated, $113,500,000, to remain available until expended, for
         the purposes of awarding and administering grants to States under this subsection.
                     
                  
                  <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                               id="HD8596097A47146558281C4E47079A000"
                               qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (b)
                     Guidance to support State implementation and operations
                     
                        138 STAT. 409
                     
                     <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                 id="H8AC3546513C14727B06E97901B054991"
                                 qb-display-quote="yes">
                        (1)
                        In general
                        
                           Deadline.
                        
                        Not later than 18 months after the date of enactment of this Act, the Secretary shall
         issue detailed guidance to States that addresses common implementation and operational
         challenges States face in ensuring access to authorized high-quality, timely, accessible
         care before, during, and after incarceration for individuals who are eligible for medical
         assistance under a State Medicaid program or child health assistance or pregnancy-related
         assistance under a State CHIP.
                     
                     <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                 id="H6A2E2D42B4314869A612A081F75AF31E"
                                 qb-display-quote="yes">
                        (2)
                        Content
                        <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                       id="H95F2CF152DA8422F86FDE9D09F3F88AC"
                                       qb-display-quote="yes">
                           (A)
                           Compliance with requirements
                           The guidance required under paragraph (1) shall address challenges States face, or
          are likely to face, in complying with the requirement described in section 1902(a)(84)(A)
          of the Social Security Act (42 U.S.C.
           1396a(a)(84)(A)) that a State shall not terminate eligibility for medical
          assistance, complying with the requirements of sections 1902(a)(84)(D) and 2102(d) of the
          Social Security Act (42 U.S.C.
           1396a(a)(84)(D), 1397bb(d)), adopting the State plan options described in the
          subdivision (A) following the last numbered paragraph of section 1905(a) and section
          2110(b)(7) of the Social Security Act (42
           U.S.C. 1396d(a), 1397jj(b)(7)), and carrying out other activities that are
          approved by the Secretary to promote continuity of care for individuals who are inmates of
          a public institution and are eligible for medical assistance under the State Medicaid
          program or are eligible for child health assistance or pregnancy-related assistance under
          the State CHIP. 
                        
                        <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                       id="H0F2C49BA76A2440D81FA112C67C2B64E"
                                       qb-display-quote="yes">
                           (B)
                           Best practices and strategies
                           The guidance required under paragraph (1) shall include best practices and strategies
          States can use to address implementation and operational challenges related to the
          requirements described in subparagraph (A), including those related to the following: 
                           <clause display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                    id="H24E36FFA091B4DAB93A56E172248DF42"
                                    qb-display-quote="yes">
                              (i)
                              Implementing modifications to improve eligibility and enrollment processes,
           including, but not limited to, completing applications for assistance under the State
           Medicaid program or the State CHIP on behalf of inmates, transmitting such applications
           to State Medicaid and CHIP agencies, and screening individuals who are inmates of public
           institutions for eligibility for medical assistance that is authorized to be furnished to
           the individual while the individual is such an inmate.
                           
                           <clause display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                    id="H3C315E844BA2420CA00AAC85FF76E21E"
                                    qb-display-quote="yes">
                              (ii)
                              Clarifying the availability of relevant Federal financial participation, including
           the administrative match under sections 1903 and 2105 of the Social Security Act
            (42 U.S.C. 1396b, 1397ee), for
           activities that directly support efforts to identify and enroll eligible individuals in
           State Medicaid programs and State CHIPs and that directly support the provision of
           authorized medical assistance, child health assistance, or pregnancy-related assistance,
           including, but not limited to, data sharing and exchange, and other necessary
           functions.
                           
                           <clause display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                    id="H22AD1F49C42E491BB6D58F4228E4DACB"
                                    qb-display-quote="yes">
                              (iii)
                              Expeditiously conducting screening for eligibility under State Medicaid programs and
           State CHIPs for individuals who are inmates of a public institution,
             
                                    138 STAT. 410
                                 
           providing application and renewal assistance for those who are not yet enrolled in such
           programs or whose eligibility needs to be renewed, and coordinating reinstatement of
           coverage under such programs with managed care enrollment.
                           
                           <clause display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                    id="H85EF38D3227047B7A42113A5FFED906C"
                                    qb-display-quote="yes">
                              (iv)
                              Ensuring that an individual who is an inmate of a public institution and is eligible
           for medical assistance under a State Medicaid program or for child health assistance or
           pregnancy-related assistance under a State CHIP receives, in a timely fashion, any such
           assistance for which Federal financial participation is authorized, such as, a supply of
           medications or prescription refill upon release and the services required under sections
           1902(a)(84)(D) and 2102(d) of the Social Security Act (42 U.S.C. 1396a(a)(84)(D), 1397bb(d)).
                           
                           <clause display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                    id="H57C37D8557154BFB8D4A7E85629D49E5"
                                    qb-display-quote="yes">
                              (v)
                              Establishing community-based provider networks, including those comprised of case
           managers, for purposes of providing continuity of care to individuals who are eligible
           for medical assistance under a State Medicaid program or child health assistance or
           pregnancy-related assistance under a State CHIP before, during, and after
           incarceration.
                           
                        
                     
                  
                  <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                               id="HC5D1F36DD3FA4C1D89010ED23CC18770"
                               qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (c)
                     Definitions
                     In this section:
                     <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                 id="H525615ED803D45DA8FF1BBB3CDF4435A"
                                 qb-display-quote="yes">
                        (1)
                        Public institution
                        The term <quote quote-display-end="auto"
                                   quote-display-start="auto"
                                   quote-type="text">public institution has the meaning given that term in section
         1902(nn)(3) of the Social Security Act (42
          U.S.C. 1396a(nn)(3)).
                     
                     <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                 id="H3CCECC821ED7458B894F5DADC9B8457A"
                                 qb-display-quote="yes">
                        (2)
                        Secretary
                        The term <quote quote-display-end="auto"
                                   quote-display-start="auto"
                                   quote-type="text">Secretary means the Secretary of Health and Human Services.
        
                     
                     <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                 id="H2309530ACB304E928F1137493CF1DE68"
                                 qb-display-quote="yes">
                        (3)
                        State
                        The term <quote quote-display-end="auto"
                                   quote-display-start="auto"
                                   quote-type="text">State has the meaning given that term in section 1101(a)(1) of
         the Social Security Act (42 U.S.C.
          1301(a)(1)) for purposes of titles XIX and XXI of such Act.
                     
                     <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                 id="H714245DEBE3A49EE93E437CC45F50617"
                                 qb-display-quote="yes">
                        (4)
                        State CHIP
                        The term <quote quote-display-end="auto"
                                   quote-display-start="auto"
                                   quote-type="text">State CHIP means a State child health plan for child health
         assistance under title XXI of the Social Security Act (42 U.S.C. 1397aa et seq.), and includes any waiver of such a plan.
        
                     
                     <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                 id="H3EB9D91DF243412282659B0EB75A65D1"
                                 qb-display-quote="yes">
                        (5)
                        State Medicaid program
                        The term <quote quote-display-end="auto"
                                   quote-display-start="auto"
                                   quote-type="text">State Medicaid program means a State plan for medical
         assistance under title XIX of the Social Security Act (42 U.S.C. 1396 et seq.), and includes any waiver of such a plan.
        
                     
                  
               
               <section display-inline="no-display-inline"
                         id="H3A2BEAF3468D4E17B2178DED3D4BDD0E"
                         qb-display-quote="yes"
                         section-type="subsequent-section">
                  207.
                  GUIDANCE RELATING TO IMPROVING THE BEHAVIORAL HEALTH WORKFORCE AND INTEGRATION OF CARE
       UNDER MEDICAID AND CHIP
                  
                     42 USC 1396a note.
                  
                  <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                               id="H8F83CB4B9FDC4676A363917EC047881D"
                               qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (a)
                     Guidance
                     
                        Deadline.
                     
                     Not later than 24 months after the date of enactment of this Act, the Secretary of
        Health and Human Services (referred to in this section as the <quote quote-display-end="auto"
                                quote-display-start="auto"
                                quote-type="text">Secretary)
        shall issue guidance to States regarding the following:
                     <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                 id="H5DA05CB6D7FD408D8BAD2D8E6E61735E"
                                 qb-display-quote="yes">
                        (1)
                        Opportunities to increase access to the mental health and substance use disorder care
         providers that participate in Medicaid or CHIP, which may include education, training,
         recruitment and retention of such providers, with a focus on improving the capacity of this
         workforce in rural and underserved areas by increasing the number, type, and capacity of
         providers. The guidance relating to such opportunities shall include the following:
           
                              138 STAT. 411
                           
                        
                        <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                       id="H1864E541185B4E0D8CD444C9F18F5843"
                                       qb-display-quote="yes">
                           (A)
                           Best practices from States that have used authorities under titles XI, XIX, or XXI of
          the Social Security Act (42 U.S.C
                              
                                 138 STAT. 197
                               . 1301
          et seq., 1396 et seq., 1397aa et seq.), including initiatives States have implemented
          under waivers under section 1115 of such Act (42 U.S.C. 1315), for such purposes.
                        
                        <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                       id="H45CD7BC40A904EE7BF7281950F949EB4"
                                       qb-display-quote="yes">
                           (B)
                           Opportunities States can leverage to finance, support, and expand the availability of
          providers of community-based mental health and substance use disorder services who
          participate in Medicaid and CHIP across the continuum of care, including through the
          participation of paraprofessionals with behavioral health expertise, such as clinicians
          with baccalaureate degrees and peer support specialists and including best practices
          especially pertinent to pediatric care. The guidance shall include examples of innovative
          policies states have adopted to expand access to behavioral health services; for example,
          by establishing more expansive and diverse behavioral health workforce roles such as
          certified wellness coaches. 
                        
                        <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                       id="H33835C0D79144D4584747AF415A65860"
                                       qb-display-quote="yes">
                           (C)
                           Best practices related to financing, supporting, and expanding the education and
          training of providers of mental health and substance use disorder services in order to
          increase the workforce of such providers who participate in Medicaid and CHIP across the
          continuum of care, including innovative public-private partnerships and including such
          practices that are especially pertinent to pediatric care. 
                        
                     
                     <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                 id="HDD5466A3A2BE4FDDA6C1BE77EBCD1D1A"
                                 qb-display-quote="yes">
                        (2)
                        Opportunities to promote the integration of mental health or substance use disorder
         services with primary care services. The guidance relating to such opportunities shall
         include the following:
                        
                           Strategies.
                        
                        <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                       id="H19ECAE83A278416E9C72729BB14DDFF2"
                                       qb-display-quote="yes">
                           (A)
                           An overview of State options for adopting and expanding value-based payment
          arrangements and alternative payment models, including accountable care organization-like
          models and other shared savings programs. 
                           
                              Overview.
                           
                        
                        <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                       id="H358AD5DDD1E54EB0AEB0B0A8873C2815"
                                       qb-display-quote="yes">
                           (B)
                           A description of opportunities for States to use and align existing authorities and
          resources to finance the integration of mental health or substance use disorder services
          with primary care services, including with respect to the use of electronic health records
          in mental health care settings and in substance use disorder care settings.
                        
                        <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                       id="HF5DEDE9A68294C6A86EE43FCABE27DC7"
                                       qb-display-quote="yes">
                           (C)
                           Strategies to support integration of mental health or substance use disorder services
          with primary care services through the use of non-clinical professionals and
          paraprofessionals, including peer support specialists. 
                        
                        <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                       id="H6B5B9CCE34BF4DE89F31BA734AA9820D"
                                       qb-display-quote="yes">
                           (D)
                           Examples of specific strategies and models designed to support integration of mental
          health or substance use disorder services with primary care services for differing age
          groups, including children and youth and individuals over the age of 65, which may include
          the collaborative care model or primary care behavioral health model for behavioral health
          integration.
                        
                     
                  
                  <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                               id="HC976C944AE844F3EB6E9F53B4148A547"
                               qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (b)
                     Integration of mental health or substance use disorder services with primary care
        services
                     For purposes of 
                           138 STAT.
         412
                         subsection (a)(2), the term <quote quote-display-end="auto"
                                quote-display-start="auto"
                                quote-type="text">integration of mental health
         or substance use disorder services with primary care services means any of the
        following: 
                     
                        Definition.
                     
                     <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                 id="H86E8E67ECABD474E8640E9EDE340EFC9"
                                 qb-display-quote="yes">
                        (1)
                        The delivery of mental health or substance use disorder services in a setting that is
         physically located in the same practice or building as a primary care setting, or when at
         least 1 provider of mental health or substance use disorder services is available in a
         primary care setting via telehealth. 
                     
                     <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                 id="HBE2652935FB94D3D8C65AE2BFB9B95BD"
                                 qb-display-quote="yes">
                        (2)
                        The use of behavioral health integration models primarily intended for pediatric
         populations with non-severe mental health needs that are focused on prevention and early
         detection and intervention methods through a multidisciplinary collaborative behavioral
         health team approach co-managed with primary care, to include same-day access to
         family-focused mental health treatment services. 
                     
                     <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                 id="H84B4B5095DEC4CC89AFEB73D264B70AA"
                                 qb-display-quote="yes">
                        (3)
                        Having providers of mental health or substance use disorder services physically
         co-located in a primary care setting with same-day visit availability.
                     
                     <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                 id="HC4B73AAA1E17435CBB54C6F71B02B986"
                                 qb-display-quote="yes">
                        (4)
                        Implementing or maintaining enhanced care coordination or targeted case management
         which includes regular interactions between and within care teams. 
                     
                     <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                 id="HC54EF2B89969488685095E7750DD4F69"
                                 qb-display-quote="yes">
                        (5)
                        Providing mental health or substance use disorder screening and follow-up assessments,
         interventions, or services within the same practice or facility as a primary care or
         physical service setting.
                     
                     <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                 id="HED578AC8EABA424A9899A5D18ACD7A0F"
                                 qb-display-quote="yes">
                        (6)
                        The use of assertive community treatment that is integrated with or facilitated by a
         primary care practice. 
                     
                     <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                 id="H8A8927A3BDE347C197BDF289B43159F9"
                                 qb-display-quote="yes">
                        (7)
                        Delivery of integrated primary care and mental health care or substance use disorder
         care in the home or in community-based settings for individuals who are recipients of
         Medicaid home and community-based services. 
                     
                  
               
               <section display-inline="no-display-inline"
                         id="H769E0819C3AB4631918C14CFD1D2E039"
                         qb-display-quote="yes"
                         section-type="subsequent-section">
                  208.
                  FUNDING FOR IMPLEMENTATION AND OPERATIONS
                  There is appropriated to the Secretary of Health and
       Human Services for fiscal year 2024, out of any funds in the Treasury not otherwise
       appropriated, to remain available until expended—
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="HD6B52DCAB13E47FE8FE9C2E1343973B2"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (1)
                     $5,000,000, for the purpose of carrying out section 203 and the amendments made by such
        section, and sections 206, and 207; and
                  
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="H1DAC092A8515462B85367519EFAE2BC0"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (2)
                     $10,000,000 for the recurring collection, analysis, and publication of health care data
        under section 1948 of the Social Security Act, as added by section 202. 
                  
               
               <section display-inline="no-display-inline"
                         id="H3C6FB228FF86470DADBCA8DB83AAEB1E"
                         qb-display-quote="yes"
                         section-type="subsequent-section">
                  209.
                  CERTIFIED COMMUNITY BEHAVIORAL HEALTH CLINIC SERVICES UNDER MEDICAID
                  <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                               id="HF641AE2BC7E841A88FB84EAAA379A1EC"
                               qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (a)
                     Definition of medical assistance
                     Section 1905 of the Social Security Act (42 U.S.C. 1396d) is amended—
                     <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                 id="H358D474D92C74E34A7EEFE4F40D55A72"
                                 qb-display-quote="yes">
                        (1)
                        in subsection (a)—
                        <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                       id="HB23FD540CE8D43A6AFDEC14F2B2F0701"
                                       qb-display-quote="yes">
                           (A)
                           in paragraph (30), by striking <quote quote-display-end="auto"
                                      quote-display-start="auto"
                                      quote-type="text">; and and inserting a semicolon;
                        
                        <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                       id="H8CE6A73E979D4F8E96AAD74742C6AE04"
                                       qb-display-quote="yes">
                           (B)
                           by redesignating paragraph (31) as paragraph (32); and
                        
                        <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                       id="H6B00562B6F3D4AFFAC49BA856B1D743A"
                                       qb-display-quote="yes">
                           (C)
                           by inserting after paragraph (30) the following new paragraph:
                           <quoted-block display-end-quotes="yes"
                                          display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                          display-quotes="yes"
                                          id="HFB96511062D84E9286E8529AA24CAB17"
                                          style="OLC">
                              <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                          id="HFFDC1B109A25485FBD5B287708F35436"
                                          qb-display-quote="yes">
                                 (31)
                                 certified community behavioral health clinic services, as defined in subsection
            (jj); and
                              
                              ; and
                           
                        
                     
                     <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                 id="HCA119CF925484BFCAED9FFC53FA50004"
                                 qb-display-quote="yes">
                        (2)
                        by adding at the end the following new subsection 
                              138 STAT. 413
                            :
                        <quoted-block display-end-quotes="yes"
                                       display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                       display-quotes="yes"
                                       id="HDA794ED43FEC418AB448739E73D76FD1"
                                       style="OLC">
                           <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                        id="H21877F96D55B4BA7862346E3F2E55FAE"
                                        qb-display-quote="yes">
                              (jj)
                              Certified community behavioral health clinic services
                              <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                          id="HEF24A53A62D94DAFAB79AEEB4238C50F"
                                          qb-display-quote="yes">
                                 (1)
                                 In general
                                 The term <quote quote-display-end="auto"
                                            quote-display-start="auto"
                                            quote-type="text">certified community behavioral health services means any of
            the following services when furnished to an individual as a patient of a certified
            community behavioral health clinic (as defined in paragraph (2)), in a manner reflecting
            person-centered care and which, if not available directly through a certified community
            behavioral health clinic, may be provided or referred through formal relationships with
            other providers:
                                 <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                                id="HF8908D3DCBEE4871821063C607D92F39"
                                                qb-display-quote="yes">
                                    (A)
                                    Crisis mental health services, including 24-hour mobile crisis teams, emergency
             crisis intervention services, and crisis stabilization.
                                 
                                 <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                                id="H382C64C650FC4A7087DA0C236A6E9D41"
                                                qb-display-quote="yes">
                                    (B)
                                    Screening, assessment, and diagnosis, including risk assessment.
                                 
                                 <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                                id="H2C018332AD07491FADA48BD9174A1ED7"
                                                qb-display-quote="yes">
                                    (C)
                                    Patient-centered treatment planning or similar processes, including risk
             assessment and crisis planning.
                                 
                                 <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                                id="H13F0BA84C1A84518B960D4ABA0AF7E60"
                                                qb-display-quote="yes">
                                    (D)
                                    Outpatient mental health and substance use services.
                                 
                                 <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                                id="H78AAE0CB98B44877A8328CD26778BCD5"
                                                qb-display-quote="yes">
                                    (E)
                                    Outpatient clinic primary care screening and monitoring of key health indicators
             and health risk.
                                 
                                 <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                                id="H8C9FA42B01E542999D6568447DD77760"
                                                qb-display-quote="yes">
                                    (F)
                                    Intensive case management services.
                                 
                                 <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                                id="H7D0D7176066A4C7A84CEE56B0BD551DC"
                                                qb-display-quote="yes">
                                    (G)
                                    Psychiatric rehabilitation services.
                                 
                                 <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                                id="H3150F9063B6C40A991BB79E697CC07E7"
                                                qb-display-quote="yes">
                                    (H)
                                    Peer support and counselor services and family supports.
                                 
                                 <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                                id="H1387B3DC596F46B78105BB65722A5A5B"
                                                qb-display-quote="yes">
                                    (I)
                                    Intensive, community-based mental health care for members of the armed forces and
             veterans who are eligible for medical assistance, particularly such members and
             veterans located in rural areas, provided the care is consistent with minimum clinical
             mental health guidelines promulgated by the Veterans Health Administration, including
             clinical guidelines contained in the Uniform Mental Health Services Handbook of such
             Administration. 
                                 
                              
                              <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                          id="H844AE2752F814E1F9C259058AEBF88AF"
                                          qb-display-quote="yes">
                                 (2)
                                 Certified community behavioral health clinic
                                 The term <quote quote-display-end="auto"
                                            quote-display-start="auto"
                                            quote-type="text">certified community behavioral health clinic means an
            organization that—
                                 <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                                id="H86B0A378A438460C89E87D2322A27BA4"
                                                qb-display-quote="yes">
                                    (A)
                                    has been certified by a State as meeting the criteria established by the Secretary
             pursuant to subsection (a) of section 223 of the Protecting Access to Medicare Act as
             of January 1, 2024, and any subsequent updates to such criteria, regardless of whether
             the State is carrying out a demonstration program under this title under subsection (d)
             of such section;
                                 
                                 <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                                id="HAD4787BF180344EAB23F31D9BA38F2CA"
                                                qb-display-quote="yes">
                                    (B)
                                    is engaged in furnishing all of the services described in paragraph (1);
             and
                                 
                                 <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                                id="HB1C5A6C0FFE1481295F932B3D68B9B0A"
                                                qb-display-quote="yes">
                                    (C)
                                    agrees, as a condition of the certification described in subparagraph (A), to
             furnish to the State or Secretary any data required as part of ongoing monitoring of
             the organization’s provision of services, including encounter data, clinical outcomes
             data, quality data, and such other data as the State or Secretary may require.
                                 
                              
                           
                           .
                        
                     
                  
                  <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                               id="H4770ECB9A5ED411BBF28045B6E0ADFF5"
                               qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (b)
                     Effective date
                     
                        42 USC 1396d note.
                     
                     The amendments made by this section shall apply with respect to medical assistance
        furnished on or after the date of enactment of this Act. 
                           138 STAT. 414
                        
                     
                  
               
               <section display-inline="no-display-inline"

                         section-type="subsequent-section">
                  210.
                  ELIMINATING CERTAIN DISPROPORTIONATE SHARE HOSPITAL PAYMENT CUTS
                  Section 1923(f)(7)(A) of the Social Security Act
        (42 U.S.C. 1396r–4(f)(7)(A)), as

       Continuing Appropriations and Other Extensions Act, 2024 (Public Law 118–35), is amended—
                  
                     Ante, p. 6.

                  PROMOTING VALUE IN MEDICAID MANAGED CARE

               <section display-inline="no-display-inline"

                  212.
                  MEDICAID IMPROVEMENT FUND
                  Section 1941(b)(3)(A) of the Social Security Act
        (42 U.S.C. 1396w–1(b)(3)(A)), as
       amended by section 122 of subtitle B of title I of division B of the Further Additional
       Continuing Appropriations and Other Extensions Act, 2024 (Public Law 118–35), is further amended by striking <quote quote-display-end="auto"
                             quote-display-start="auto"
                             quote-type="text">$5,140,428,729
       and inserting <quote quote-display-end="auto"
                             quote-display-start="auto"
                             quote-type="text">$0. 
               
            
            <subtitle id="H30EA896D75754D95A7505F8C6E5A5725"
                       qb-display-quote="yes"
                       style="OLC">
               C
               Medicare
               <section display-inline="no-display-inline"
                         id="H17CD98E023D84229BF3C32787DB54618"
                         qb-display-quote="yes"
                         section-type="subsequent-section">
                  301.
                  EXTENSION OF FUNDING FOR QUALITY MEASURE ENDORSEMENT, INPUT, AND SELECTION
                  Section 1890(d)(2) of the Social Security Act
        (42 U.S.C. 1395aaa(d)(2)) is
       amended—
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="H7C984FE5F20E4A28BDC80F1F6847C603"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (1)
                     in the first sentence—
                     <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                    id="HA37C646E3555407392054A3AA50E57F4"
                                    qb-display-quote="yes">
                        (A)
                        by striking <quote quote-display-end="auto"
                                   quote-display-start="auto"
                                   quote-type="text">and $20,000,000 and inserting <quote quote-display-end="auto"
                                   quote-display-start="auto"
                                   quote-type="text">$20,000,000;
         and
                     
                     <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                    id="H59C940B8E9CD44808BC938E0D6268B21"
                                    qb-display-quote="yes">
                        (B)
                        by inserting the following before the period at the end: <quote quote-display-end="auto"
                                   quote-display-start="auto"
                                   quote-type="text">, and $9,000,000 for
          the period beginning on October 1, 2023, and ending on December 31, 2024;
         and
                     
                  
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="H2833E1B63C2A40DBA80A79FD9E36B7E1"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (2)
                     in the third sentence, by striking <quote quote-display-end="auto"
                                quote-display-start="auto"

            <subtitle id="HB9ED5FF8C95E4EF192D88C5A6709C22B"
                       qb-display-quote="yes"
                       style="OLC">
               D
               Human Services
               <section display-inline="no-display-inline"
                         id="H157F613E4EBD47D593AFAE5BB32F8E4F"
                         qb-display-quote="yes"
                         section-type="subsequent-section">
                  401.
                  EXTENSION OF TEMPORARY ASSISTANCE FOR NEEDY FAMILIES PROGRAM
                  
                     42 USC 601 note.
                  
                  Activities authorized by part A of title IV (other
       than under section 403(c) or 418) and section 1108(b) of the Social Security Act shall
       continue through September 30, 2024, in the manner authorized for fiscal year 2023, and out
       of any money in the Treasury of the United States not otherwise appropriated, there are
       hereby appropriated such sums as may be necessary for such purpose.
               
               <section display-inline="no-display-inline"
                         id="H7824FA0FF96D405AA833EEA2A2F4A16A"
                         qb-display-quote="yes"
                         section-type="subsequent-section">
                  402.
                  EXTENSION OF CHILD AND FAMILY SERVICES PROGRAMS
                  Activities authorized by part B of title IV of the
       Social Security Act shall continue through December 31, 2024, in the manner authorized for
       fiscal year 2023, and out of any money in the Treasury of the United States not otherwise
       appropriated, there are hereby appropriated such sums as may be necessary for such
       purpose.

         <title id="HC52AD258C33B4A3AB4808FE9680B39CB"
                 qb-display-quote="yes"
                 style="OLC">
            II
            AMENDING COMPACTS OF FREE ASSOCIATION
            
               Department of Justice Appropriations Act, 2024.
            
            <section display-inline="no-display-inline"
                      id="HCA03A04AA20342B892A8A9C32A6C3F8D"
                      qb-display-quote="yes"
                      section-type="subsequent-section">
               201.
               SHORT TITLE
               This title may be cited as the <quote quote-display-end="auto"
                          quote-display-start="auto"
                          quote-type="text">
                     Compact of Free Association Amendments Act of
        2024
                  .
            
            <section display-inline="no-display-inline"
                      id="HDAB1802C069D4C82B04F6CD60F0F5158"
                      qb-display-quote="yes"
                      section-type="subsequent-section">
               202.
               FINDINGS
               
                  48 USC 1981.
               
               Congress finds the following: 
               <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                           id="HBD0161BF06FF400E9C315F68DE30C654"
                           qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (1)
                  The United States (in accordance with the Trusteeship Agreement for the Trust Territory
       of the Pacific Islands, the United Nations Charter, and the objectives of the international
       trusteeship system of the United Nations) fulfilled its obligations to promote the
       development of the people of the Trust Territory toward self-government or independence, as
       appropriate, to the particular circumstances of the Trust Territory 
                        138 STAT. 420
                      and the people of the Trust
       Territory and the freely expressed wishes of the people concerned.
               
               <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                           id="HD888469E558F4923B3409BBF88CBACAA"
                           qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (2)
                  The United States, the Federated States of Micronesia, and the Republic of the Marshall
       Islands entered into the Compact of Free Association set forth in section 201 of the Compact
       of Free Association Act of 1985 (48 U.S.C.
        1901 note; Public Law 99–239) and the
       United States and the Republic of Palau entered into the Compact of Free Association set
       forth in section 201 of Public Law 99–658
        (48 U.S.C. 1931 note) to create and
       maintain a close and mutually beneficial relationship.
               
               <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                           id="H859239E6AE3241A0922B6EEDB759F5C2"
                           qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (3)
                  The <quote quote-display-end="auto"
                             quote-display-start="auto"
                             quote-type="text">Compact of Free Association, as amended, between the Government of the United
        States of America and the Government of the Federated States of Micronesia, the
        <quote quote-display-end="auto"
                             quote-display-start="auto"
                             quote-type="text">Compact of Free Association, as amended, between the Government of the United States
        of America and the Government of the Republic of the Marshall Islands, and related
       agreements were signed by the Government of the United States and the Governments of the
       Federated States of Micronesia and the Republic of the Marshall Islands and approved, as
       applicable, by section 201 of the Compact of Free Association Amendments Act of 2003
        (48 U.S.C. 1921 note; Public Law 108–188).
               
               <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                           id="H8844D1FCBEE84A65B4A5EB79A52193AA"
                           qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (4)
                  The <quote quote-display-end="auto"
                             quote-display-start="auto"
                             quote-type="text">Agreement between the Government of the United States of America and the
        Government of the Republic of Palau Following the Compact of Free Association Section 432
        Review, was signed by the Government of the United States and the Government of the
       Republic of Palau on September 3, 2010, and amended on September 19, 2018.
               
               <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                           id="HAE080818647B48EA8DBDCB3A285BC08D"
                           qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (5)
                  On May 22, 2023, the United States signed the <quote quote-display-end="auto"
                             quote-display-start="auto"
                             quote-type="text">Agreement between the Government of
        the United States of America and the Government of the Republic of Palau Resulting From the
        2023 Compact of Free Association Section 432 Review.
               
               <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                           id="H97E939FFF8C143808F0C124DA1134249"
                           qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (6)
                  On May 23, 2023, the United States signed 3 agreements related to the U.S.-FSM Compact
       of Free Association, including an Agreement to Amend the Compact, as amended, a new fiscal
       procedures agreement, and a new trust fund agreement and on September 28, 2023, the United
       States signed a Federal Programs and Services agreement related to the U.S.-FSM Compact of
       Free Association.
               
               <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                           id="H77BC1CC7D73945389F92AE694BE89316"
                           qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (7)
                  On October 16, 2023, the United States signed 3 agreements relating to the U.S.-RMI
       Compact of Free Association, including an Agreement to Amend the Compact, as amended, a new
       fiscal procedures agreement, and a new trust fund agreement.
               
            
            <section display-inline="no-display-inline"
                      id="H33A764B4850F40478681D41A5253FC46"
                      qb-display-quote="yes"
                      section-type="subsequent-section">
               203.
               DEFINITIONS
               
                  48 USC 1982.
               
               In this title:
               <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                           id="HAC19FAC02EF641D59CC1717BD8D82C47"
                           qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (1)
                  1986 Compact
                  The term <quote quote-display-end="auto"
                             quote-display-start="auto"
                             quote-type="text">1986 Compact means the Compact of Free Association between the
       Government of the United States and the Governments of the Marshall Islands and the Federated
       States of Micronesia set forth in section 201 of the Compact of Free Association Act of 1985
        (48 U.S.C. 1901 note; Public Law 99–239). 
               
               <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                           id="HDF03C0EBDFD441F28BC4A83CEB67EA88"
                           qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (2)
                  2003 Amended U.S.-FSM Compact
                  The term <quote quote-display-end="auto"
                             quote-display-start="auto"
                             quote-type="text">2003 Amended U.S.-FSM Compact means the Compact of Free
       Association amending the 1986 Compact entitled the <quote quote-display-end="auto"
                             quote-display-start="auto"
                             quote-type="text">Compact of Free Association, as
        amended, between the Government of 
                           138 STAT.
          421
                         the United States of America and the Government of the
        Federated States of Micronesia set forth in section 201(a) of the Compact of Free
       Association Amendments Act of 2003 (48 U.S.C.
        1921 note; Public Law
       108–188).
               
               <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                           id="HBAAD2ED2411D427EBC2212102D4655AF"
                           qb-display-quote="yes">

                             quote-display-start="auto"
                             quote-type="text">2003 Amended U.S.-RMI Compact means the Compact of Free
       Association amending the 1986 Compact entitled <quote quote-display-end="auto"
                             quote-display-start="auto"
                             quote-type="text">Compact of Free Association, as
        amended, between the Government of the United States of America and the Government of the
        Republic of the Marshall Islands set forth in section 201(b) of the Compact of Free
       Association Amendments Act of 2003 (48 U.S.C.
        1921 note; Public Law
       108–188).

            <section display-inline="no-display-inline"
                      id="HE44D9821B1CE4C02B8496BBE14A7B9E9"
                      qb-display-quote="yes"
                      section-type="subsequent-section">
               204.
               APPROVAL OF 2023 AGREEMENT TO AMEND THE U.S.-FSM COMPACT, 2023 AGREEMENT TO AMEND THE
      U.S.-RMI COMPACT, 2023 U.S.-PALAU COMPACT REVIEW AGREEMENT, AND SUBSIDIARY AGREEMENTS
               
                  48 USC 1983.
               
               <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                            id="HFE4016C5DC4D4A7690E9B97F9984CBD7"
                            qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (a)
                  Federated States of Micronesia
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="H05E797E574AF4A03A409AA3C12EAB5D7"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (1)
                     Approval
                     
                        48 USC 1921 note.
                     
                     The 2023 Agreement to Amend the U.S.-FSM Compact and the 2023 U.S.-FSM Trust Fund
        Agreement, as submitted to Congress on June 15, 2023, are approved and incorporated by
        reference.
                  
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="H4D00E59237DE4E0F84EBB6DFD5315C1F"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (2)
                     Consent of Congress
                     Congress consents to—
                     <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                    id="H52DA6A93AC2E4525B1E509BEF5AD8291"
                                    qb-display-quote="yes">
                        (A)
                        the 2023 U.S.-FSM Fiscal Procedures Agreement, as submitted to Congress on June 15,
         2023; and 
                     
                     <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                    id="H49DED9EB0C1E4B2EBE010B003377F736"
                                    qb-display-quote="yes">
                        (B)
                        the 2023 U.S.-FSM Federal Programs and Services Agreement.
                     
                  
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="H1BE4F4EAEEC74B18A067AA1589AC37C8"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (3)
                     Authority of President
                     Notwithstanding section 101(f) of the Compact of Free Association Amendments Act of
        2003 (48 U.S.C. 1921(f)), the
        President is authorized to bring into force and implement the agreements described in
        paragraphs (1) and (2).
                  
               
               <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                            id="HBB2DFB534CCA4FD3914F1DF8EF3BB31E"
                            qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (b)
                  Republic of the Marshall Islands
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="H983DC465A0034CF5883EF97F9F758E4C"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (1)
                     Approval
                     
                        48 USC 1921 note.
                     
                     The 2023 Agreement to Amend the U.S.-RMI Compact and the 2023 U.S.-RMI Trust Fund
        Agreement, as submitted to Congress on October 17, 2023, are approved and incorporated by
        reference. 
                  
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="H04B63E2786B141A0A8FDD440E3473CAE"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (2)
                     Consent of congress
                     Congress consents to the 2023 U.S.-RMI Fiscal Procedures Agreement, as submitted to
        Congress on October 17, 2023.
                  
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="H9F6ABB598AA441C59463CFF704541C30"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">

        2003 (48 U.S.C. 1921(f)), the
        President is authorized to bring into force and implement the agreements described in
        paragraphs (1) and (2). 
                  
               
               <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                            id="H84E8D39F82CF4F63A6640804B65C1141"
                            qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (c)
                  Republic of Palau
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="H8B4600BA28EB4B2984754C9902BB656B"

        2023, is approved.
                  
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
